abstract.para: Valkey is designed to be a seamless replacement, maintaining compatibility with the Redis API, protocol, persistence data, ports, and configuration files. The transition from Redis to Valkey is easy for many basic setups. The following procedure assumes Redis is installed,running and loaded with data.

procedure.title: How to migrate from Redis to Valkey

step.para: Check the current Redis server version:
step.screen: &prompt.user; redis-cli info server # Server redis_version:7.2.4 redis_git_sha1:00000000 redis_git_dirty:0 redis_build_id:8c22b097984bd350 redis_mode:standalone [...]

step.para: On a new install of Redis, add some data to a key so that it is visible in Valkey:
Install valkey-compat-redis package with the --force-resolution option:
step.screen:
&prompt.sudo; # zypper in --force-resolution valkey-compat-redis Refreshing service 'NVIDIA'. Refreshing service 'openSUSE'. Loading repository data... Reading installed packages... Resolving package dependencies...

step.para: The packages takes your existing configuration files and persistence data and moves them to Valkey with no additional steps required. Since Valkey is fully compatible with the Redis API,protocol,persistence data,ports and configuration files.

step.screen: &prompt.user; redis-cli info server # Server redis_version:7.2.4 server_name:valkey valkey_version:7.2.5 redis_git_sha1:00000000 redis_git_dirty:0 redis_build_id:b0d9f188ef999bd3 redis_mode:standalone [...]
step.para: Valkey is responsive to both redis_version:7.2.4 and valkey_version:7.2.5 Retaining the redis_version ensures maximum compatibility while still identifying the server with valkey_version. alkey has a binary named valkey-cli but symbolically links redis-cli. Both CLIs have the same functionality.
